Package com.esri.mo2.src.sys

Definition of the Content API interfaces and base classes.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Connection An interface Connection provides the access information necessary to connect to a Source.
Content This interface represents objects that can be accessed through a Connection.
ContentVisitor You can traverse a Folder tree by providing an implementation of LayerVisitor and calling ContentUtility's traverse method.
Folder This is a container for other objects accessed thru a Connection
Source a Source represents an external source of data, such as a database or file system.
WritableContent Folders may optionally produce Content that is writable depending on the access rights of the user.
WritableFolder a Folder may optionally be writable depending on the access rights of the user.
 

Class Summary
BaseContent this class provides support for the Comparable interface, by providing a compareTo() implementation that uses the Content's name as comparator value.
BaseFolder base class implementation for a file system folder.
BaseSource This base class provides default implementations for Source
ContentUtility Various utilities for defining and accessing Content via an "access string".
InvalidContent This class acts as a placekeeper for Content objects that have some underlying error associated with their construction.
Properties This class provides a defined ordering to the keys of a HashMap.
RenderingUtility Provides support for a standardized rendering of FeatureLayers.
ResourceBundle Provides access to the resource bundle used for all Source-related text.
SourceCache Sources may be cached here, so that Datasets produced from this Source are unique.
 

Exception Summary
ContentUtility.InvalidAccessStringException this exception is thrown within accessContent() if the access String is invalid
 

Package com.esri.mo2.src.sys Description

Definition of the Content API interfaces and base classes. Using this api, applications can connect to GIS objects such as a Dataset or Layer and, once connected, use them without concern for the underlying connection.

The first step in the process for connecting to a particular GIS object is to construct a Connection object, using one of the implementations. Currently, these are available for accessing objects within the local file system (com.esri.mo2.src.file.FileSystemConnection), ArcSDE databases (com.esri.mo2.client.sde.SdeConnection), and ArcIMS 4 services (com.esri.mo2.client.aims.ArcIms4Connection). Each Connection implementation is normally constructed using one or more String parameters that define connection details that are appropriate for that implementation, such as database username and password, or Web address.

Once a Connection object is constructed, an application then opens a Source that manages objects relating to that Connection. There are two ways to do this:

  • using the cache via SourceCache.getSource(Connection)
  • avoiding the cache via Connection.constructSource()
It is the application developer's choice whether or not to use the Cache. The advantage of using the Cache is to ensure that GIS objects obtained are unique for a given object location. Of course, maintaining a cache can drain memory resources, so simple applications might not need caching capabilities and are therefore not required to use the cache.

To obtain Content from a Source, an application must connect to the Source, and once used, the application may disconnect the Source, with the possibility of reconnecting later if need be. An application can only use Content while the parent Source remains connected. If the Source is disconnected, then the Content is not guaranteed to be useful or work properly, unless the Source becomes once again reconnected.

Applications may obtain Content from a Source in two ways:

  • through discovery via Source.getRoots(), and
  • through direct access using a path via Source.getContent()
Using the discovery approach, an application obtains one or more root Content objects. Such Content objects may or may not be instances of Folder. If a Folder, then further Content can be obtained from the Folder. Folders provide a hierarchical structure in a similar fashion to the local disk system hierarchy. Actually, for the FileSystemConnection, the disk hierarchy is mirrored exactly by the Folder and Content hierarchy. For other Connection implementations, the hierarchy is described in the relevant package documentation.

Using the direct approach, a path string is used to uniquely identify a particular object. The path describes the location of a particular Content within the Folder hierarchy for the Connection implementation. The details for this hierarchy and path are described in the package documentation for the particular Connection.

A typical sequence for accessing Content (using the cache and direct access) is like this:

   Connection connection = new ConnectionImplementation(zero-or-more-string-parameters);
   try {
      Source source = SourceCache.getSource(connection);
      source.connect();  
      Content content = source.getContent("path to content");
   }
   catch(java.io.IOException ex) {
      ex.printStackTrace();
   }
Once a Content object has been obtained, underlying GIS objects can be obtained and then used. A Content basically represents a single object located in some external database or file system; however, the same object can be represented in one of several ways. For instance, an ESRI shapefile can be accessed as a FeatureClass or a FeatureLayer. Each Content object obtained from a Source has a list of available Content-types. These are defined to be the full Java class path of GIS object types that can be obtained from the Content using Content.getData(String). The String parameter is the full path name of a Java class, typically obtained from java.lang.Class.getName(), indicating the desired Content-type.

Content-types for a particular Content can be discovered using Content.getAvailableContentTypes(). In some applications, the Content-type may be known in advance, for example, if a shapefile is expected, there is no need to "discover" if the Content has a FeatureClass Content-type, instead the application may directly obtain the FeatureClass by specifying the String class path for FeatureClass. Here is a complete example:

   Connection connection = new FileSystemConnection();
   try {
      Source source = SourceCache.getSource(connection);
      if (!source.isConnected()) source.connect();
      Content content = source.getContent("/esridata/canada/province.shp");
   }
   catch(java.io.IOException ex) {
     ex.printStackTrace();
   }
   FeatureClass fclass = (FeatureClass)content.getData(FeatureClass.class.getName());
It is also possible to be "less specific" when requesting a particular Content-type. This is made possible because Content.getData() will compare the requested Content-type with the Content-type "declared" within Content.getAvailableContentTypes(). If the requested Content-type is a super-class or interface of one of the declared Content-types, then the corresponding GIS object will be returned by Content.getData(). This functionality is useful for applications that need to generically handle multiple object types.

Suppose in the above example of a shapefile an application wishes to obtain a Layer to add to a Map. The application does not need to "know" that the object actually is a shapefile and consequently does not need to request a FeatureLayer but instead can request a generic Layer as follows: for example:

   Map map...;
   Connection connection = new FileSystemConnection();
   try {
      Source source = SourceCache.getSource(connection);
      if (!source.isConnected()) source.connect();
      Content content = source.getContent("/esridata/canada/province.shp");
      Layer layer = (Layer)content.getData(Layer.class.getName());
      map.getLayerset().addLayer(layer);
   }
   catch(java.io.IOException ex) {
      ex.printStackTrace();
   }
